transcript: today I want to introduce you to network ports more specifically access and trunk ports these are the big players when it comes to managing traffic on your network knowing how they differ and when to use them is like having a secret weapon for your network setup in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain access and trunk ports for beginners [Music] next I'll start with access ports they're all about one-on-one connections hooking up a single device to a specific network if the network were compared to a highway it would be like giving each device its own exclusive private Lane to travel through it adds an extra degree of protection to make sure data travels securely and efficiently they are often used to connect devices such as PCS printers and servers to the switch when you set up an access port it is designed to carry traffic for just one virtual local area network VLAN by default the switch comes with one VLAN VLAN one all ports have VLAN one assigned to them when you add vlans to Ports you can change the assignments access ports are simple to configure but they don't provide much flexibility or scalability if if a device needs to communicate with devices on another VLAN it must travel through a router or layer 3 switch now on the flip side are Trunk ports if access ports are the private Lanes then trunk ports are the bustling highways of the network a trunk is a point-to-point connection between one networking device and another trunk ports connect two or more vlans on an interface they can trans transport traffic from many VLS across a single connection allowing you to extend VLS across an entire network these ports are multitaskers making sure all data packets get to where they need to be this is done by tagging each packet with a unique identifier the VLAN ID so it doesn't get mixed up with the others trunk ports make better use of bandwidth by allowing many vlans to share the same physical link however they're not considered as secure as access ports the key thing that sets access and trunk ports apart is their function and how you use them while access ports link individual network devices to their assigned vlans trunk ports connect multiple vlans to the other parts of the network this difference is crucial the way you configure these ports directly affects how efficient secure and high performing your network will be deciding whether to use all access ports all trunk ports or some of each depends on what your network needs by default every port on Catalyst 1 1200 and 1300 switches are in Access mode for smaller networks with few devices access ports will work just fine but as your network grows and traffic becomes busier you may want to start using trunk ports there you have it now that you know about access and trunk ports you can design a more robust and capable network if you're ready to configure this on your Catalyst 1200 or 1300 switch check out the link in the description thanks for watching I'll title: Cisco Tech Talk: CLI Basics #3: Shortcuts and Tips

type w another option is to hit the tab button on the keyboard to autocomplete a command word this works as long as there is only one option that fits to demonstrate this instead of typing the command added to the command line another time-saving tip is to use the command history Cisco CLI keeps a record of all commands you have entered in a session specific to each mode to enter one of these commands again in that same mode you can Arrow up or down and select the command instead of typing it out again when you go through the command history you can also modify commands and use them again you can move the cursor left and right with the keyboard arrows if you need to change something within the command to move the cursor to the beginning of the line click control+ a to move the cursor to the end of the command click ctrl+ e by Design certain commands are only available in specific modes and you need to be in the correct mode to execute the commands however there is an exception to this the do command on Cisco small business switches you can be in a higher level command mode and still execute a privileged exec Command right from the configuration mode this saves the time of backing out to the correct mode running the show command and then going step by by step back into the sub mode for the next step all you have to do is add the word do to the beginning of the command once you see the output you can easily continue configurations still in the sub mode I'll enter do show VLAN as an example if you want to disable a feature or function that already has been applied you can use a no command almost every configuration command has a no form use the command without the word no keyword to reenable a disabled feature or to enable a feature that is disabled by default I'll enter no IP routing to demonstrate don't forget to exit and save any new configurations with a copy running-config startup-config or the abbreviated command of w there you have it the basics of CLI you now know how to get connected identify the command modes and prompt changes get in and back out of each mode get context sensitive help use shortcuts and more when you're ready build on this knowledge and try it for yourself thanks for watching I'll see you next [Music] time

modes I'll start by entering the username and password for privilege level one user exec mode user exec mode lets you see configurations View files see the current software version and perform other basic commands user mode is indicated by a greater than symbol after the host name although user mode doesn't provide the power to make changes show commands provide crucial information on the status and configuration details of the network they're often used for troubleshooting and monitoring when you make changes you can check to make sure they've been applied with a show command privileged exec or administrative mode level 15 allows access to everything including big changes to the network this includes installing new software or altering systems settings to elevate from user mode to privilege mode enter the command enable then enter the password usually privileged exact mode is indicated by a hashtag symbol after the host name alternatively you can jump right into privileged exact mode by entering the level 15 username and password as shown here the hashtag verifies it when you have privileged exec access you can enter commands to get you to any of the configuration modes each command mode gives you access to a different set of commands and functionalities allowing you to perform specific tasks and configure particular aspects of the system to move from privileged access mode to Global configuration mode use the configure terminal command once this command is entered you will see the prompt change to show the word config in parentheses before the hashtag this confirms that you are in global configuration mode here you can make General changes to the running configuration of the switch if you want to make changes to a specific interface or line you need to First access Global configuration mode and then the interface or line mode these are sub modes for example I'll enter interface gigabit Ethernet 1/06 this puts me in the sub mode of interface configuration for that Port from there you can even enter a Sub sub mode I won't go into the details for this but I do want to mention that the mode you are in is always reflected in the prompt so if transcript: today I'm going to introduce you to SNMP the simple Network management protocol this protocol keeps network communication in order Network administrators lean on SNMP to keep their networks running like a well-oiled machine troubleshoot any issues and strategically plan for the Network's future in this first of a two-part episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain the basics of SNMP next with smmp you can gather useful information from network devices this includes finding out the name and type of device how long it's been running and if it's working okay you can see how much data it's handling and if there are any problems with the connections it's also handy for checking on the health of your devices like if they're running hot or using too much memory or CPU power plus you can peek at the Network's performance like speed and quality and even keep an eye on security on top of all that SNMP lets you look at details like Voiceover IP quality how much storage you've got left and even the nitty-gritty on power supplies it's like having a window into every corner of your network making sure everything's running smoothly and letting you know something's up SNMP works with UDP Port 161 for the usual conversations between the SNMP manager and the network agents when an agent needs to flag something important it sends what's called a trap over UDP Port 162 to the manager SNMP helps cut down on the expenses tied to network monitoring and increases the overall dependability of your system what's great is that SNMP isn't set in stone it's an open standard which means it's flexible and can be expanded to suit the needs of your network one of the key parts of SNMP is the management information base MIB it's sort of like a virtual library where all the important Network information is stored this library is split into sections with lots of variables that can be adjusted by the SNMP agents or by the central control system an SNMP agent is a small piece of software that lives on a network device keeping tabs on what the device is doing and sending updates to the SNMP manager the manager is where all the monitoring action happens keeping an eye on all the agents out there and managing them as needed SNMP has evolved over time to meet the security and functionality needs of modern networks there are three main versions of SNMP the original SNMP V1 has a straightforward security system SNMP v2c or version 2 Community Based came along long to refine the original but didn't change the security much snmpv3 was a GameChanger introducing robust security measures such as message Integrity authentication and encryption offering a more secure way to manage and monitor network operations although considered the latest and greatest version 3 may not be the best fit for all if a network is older or near capacity the additional security measures can cause delays older Network gear or devices on a network may not be compatible it can be a bit tricky to set up and if enhanced security isn't a priority it may not be worth the extra effort despite these potential roadblocks SNMP V3 is recommended and encouraged as an overall security strategy no matter what version of SNMP you use the basic set of commands or operations are the same they're used to gather and organize information for monitoring and management SNMP get is for when the network management needs to collect specific data from an agent it's broken down into a few different variations get fetches a specific data point get next goes to the next data point in the sequence and get bulk gathers a lot of data at once to save time SNMP set allows you to tweak the data that a device is storing and SNMP notifications are alerts from Agents to the manager about any significant happenings without being prompted traps send out alerts about network issues informs are like traps but they also look for confirmation back from the manager that in a nutshell is an overview of SNMP its purpose functions and its place in the world of network management click the link in the description to be brought to part two where I'll show you SNMP in action thanks for watching I'll see you soon [Music]

management data packets might just keep bouncing between switches without ever reaching their destination this causes what's called a network loop which leads to congestion now throw in broadcast frames those are the messages sent to all devices within a certain area and you've got a recipe for trouble if caught in a loop these broadcasts can multiply clogging up the Network's bandwidth and potentially bringing it to a halt to tackle this you need the spanning tree protocol STP it's like a traffic director deciding which Pathways to close off so data flows smoothly without any Loops over time different flavors of STP have been developed each with enhancements to keep networks running more efficiently but there's no Universal best choice it depends on your Network's specific needs in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain the distinct features and benefits of each STP variation [Music] next I'll start with the original STP it's defined by the I E 802.1d standard and is also known as common spanning tree CST STP was designed to support a single spanning tree instance for the entire Bridge Network this can cause slow convergence and less than optimal traffic flows if you have a small simple Network STP may be all you need pervan spanning tree plus is a Cisco enhanced version that creates a distinct 802.1d spanning tree for each VLAN within the network this means that each VLAN can have its own optimized path this is done to improve Network efficiency however if you have a lot of vlans you have to be careful these individual instances increase the CPU and memory usage if your network doesn't have the capacity for this it can cause problems on the network if you have a Cisco network with enough capacity and VLAN specific optimization is important to you this would be a good fit moving toward faster convergence times rapid spanning tree protocol rstp is defined by the i e 802.1w standard and also serves as an evolution of the original STP our STP significantly improves Network recovery times after topology changes if network uptime is your number one priority you may want want to select rstp rapid per VLAN spanning tree plus is Cisco's version of rstp it incorporates the benefits of pvst plus offering a separate instance of 802.1w for each VLAN the blend of Rapid convergence and per VLAN optimization makes it a good choice for Cisco Centric environments with multiple vlans that need quick recovery from failures the last option multiple spanning tree protocol mstp is defined by i e 802.1s it takes a different approach by mapping multiple vlans into a single spanning tree instance Cisco's implementation of this is known as multiple spanning tree MST this approach can reduce the resource load on network devices by decreasing the number of required instances while still providing faster convergence than the original STP mstp has VLAN mapping efficiency like no other if you have a large Network and are concerned about scalability this may be a good option for you on Cisco Catalyst 1200 and 1300 series switches you have some detailed selections you can make for STP in the web user interface menu under spanning tree click STP status and global settings here you can adjust the spanning tree State STP Loop loop backu stdp operation mode bpdu handling setting path cost default values and Bridge parameters one other option here is to switch the mode from basic to Advanced in the upper right hand corner of the screen on this Catalyst switch advanced mode gives you access to more configuration choices when setting up mstp and pbst the options for STP vary based on the model of the switch that's a wrap for this stdp beginners guide now you know the benefits and potential drawbacks of each and can decide which is the best fit for your network thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: in asymmetric routing data packets Take One path to reach their destination and a different path on their way back this may not sound like a big deal but it can lead to issues when stateful firewalls are part of the network path in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain asymmetric routing some issues it can cause and how to reconfigure your network to prevent it next [Music] a firewall with stateful packet inspection looks closely at the first packet of data when it starts a new connection it remembers this information and keeps track of the conversation or flow if a packet comes in and it's part of the conversation the firewall remembers it lets it through conversely if the packet does not match or is not associated with an existing flow it is dropped protocols that maintain State information such as HTTP and TCP may be affected by asymmetric routing while stateless protocols such as icmp may not to illustrate the impact of asymmetric routing consider the following Network diagram in this network there is a layer 3 switch and a firewall with stateful packet inspection capabilities connected via a trunk link the switch has two connected devices a PC and a server each belonging to different vlans and subnets the firewall serves as the default gateway for the PC while the layer 3 switch is the default gateway for the server when the PC attempts to initiate a three-way TCP handshake with the server it sends a TCP sin packet to its default gateway the firewall the firewall then forwards the packet to the server in response the server sends a synac message which is directed to its default gateway the layer 3 switch the layer 3 switch consults its forwarding table and finds that the PC's VLAN is directly connected so it forwards the synak message directly to the PC the PC then attempts to complete the hand Shake by sending a TCP act message back to the server through the firewall its default gateway however the firewall performing stateful packet inspection drops this act packet because it did not see the syac coming from the server and therefore has no established Flow State for this connection in practice to demonstrate this Behavior a layer 3 switch could be connected to an RV 34 45 router with firewall capabilities that include stateful inspection for example two ipv4 interfaces on the switch could be set up for VLAN 1 and VLAN 2 with corresponding interfaces configured on the router the router and switch would be connected via a trunk link a PC might be connected to an access port on the switch that is a member of VLAN 2 with a static IP address configured and the fire firewalls IP address in VLAN 2 set as its default gateway a server with an IP address in VLAN 1 might also be connected in this setup while the server responds to Ping requests attempts to access it through other protocols May Fail checking the firewall logs would reveal that the firewall is dropping the TCP act messages from the PC to resolve this a few reconfigurations are needed on the network work set up the firewall or the switch as the default gateway for both the server and the PC in this example by changing the default gateway on the PC to the IP address of the layer 3 switch within VLAN 2 the asymmetric routing issue will be resolved there you have it the basics of asymmetric routing and how to prevent it in your network thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

constant communication and computation that Dynamic routing protocols do while static IP routes offer many benefits they also come with limitations scalability can be an issue in large dynamic networks managing static routes can become convers some and lead to errors they can be timec consuming to maintain since they don't adapt when there is a change in the network topology or if there's a failure manual updates need to be done if they aren't done quickly or properly there will be problems in the network by understanding when and how to use static routes you can ensure efficient and reliable Network performance one static route that almost every network administrator sets up is a default route a default route directs all traffic that doesn't match any other specific routes in the routing table to a designated next hop typically a router that connects to the internet or another large Network this ensures that any data packets with unknown destinations can still be forwarded appropriately providing a catch-all path for outbound traffic and ensuring basic network connectivity to match any destination Network address and subnet map 0.0.0.0 is used for both there you have it the basics of static routes click the link in the description for part two where I'll show you how to configure them thanks for watching I'll see you soon [Music]

no conflict to demonstrate static routing I have connected my PC labeled PC3 to an access port that is a member of VLAN 15 on layer 3 switch I've assigned a static IP address to my PC which resides Port one on each switch in the ipv4 configuration I will set a static route indicating that to access network 10.20 20.0 sl24 packets must be directed to the next hop which is the IP address of layer title: Cisco Tech Talk: How to Change Your DNS Settings with Google DNS, OpenDNS & Cloudflare - Part 1
description:
Are you looking to boost your internet speed, reliability, and security? In this first of a two-part series of Cisco Tech Talk, we break down what the Domain Name System (DNS) is and show you step-by-step how to change your DNS settings on Windows, iPhone (iOS 17), and Android (Android 14) devices using popular public DNS servers like Google DNS, OpenDNS, and Cloudflare. 
 
Stay tuned for part 2 next week!

transcript: The domain name system DNS is like the internet's phone book. When an easily remembered website like cisco.com is entered into a browser, it looks up its corresponding unique IP address and changes the search to that address. This is necessary for devices to communicate with other devices on the internet. Most businesses use the default DNS servers that come with their internet service provider ISP for this. However, there are public DNS servers you can use instead, which can provide some good benefits. In this first of a two-part episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll explain some benefits of using a public DNS server and show you how to change it on some individual devices. Next, [Music] Public DNS servers are managed by thirdparty companies and are open for anyone to use. They can be a good alternative. Public DNS servers often load websites faster, have better uptime and fewer outages, and may even provide additional security and privacy. Some of the most popular are Google DNS, Open DNS and Cloudflare. They provide both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses. You can change the DNS server on different devices. Where you change the DNS settings depends on how widely you want the changes to apply and how much control you need. I will demonstrate the process on a few different devices. To keep it simple, I will use Google DNS for all of them. You can set a Windows computer to use a public DNS server with a few simple steps. Open the control panel on your computer. Select network and internet and then network connections. Doubleclick on your connection. Click properties. I'll select the IPv4 option. Enter the DNS server addresses you prefer. I'll enter 8.8. 8.8.8 as the preferred DNS server and 8.8.4.4 as the alternate. This setting applies to this one computer. You can also change your cell phone to use a public DNS server. To set this up on an iPhone iOS version 17, open settings, select the wireless network, and click the I next to the network name. Scroll down and select configure DNS. Choose manual. Delete the existing DNS server address and enter the public DNS server addresses. Click save in the top right corner of the screen. To change the DNS settings on an Android version 14, start by scrolling down the menu and selecting Wi-Fi. Choose the SSID that you're connected to. Click on settings, then view more options. If you are using DHCP, like in this example, you can't change the DNS settings. Switch this over to static. Keep this same IP address as before and ensure the gateway remains unchanged. For DNS, I'll switch to the public DNS server and then click save to apply the changes. Depending on your device and software version, these new settings may not transfer when you connect to a new wireless network. If they don't, you'll need to repeat the steps to apply when using this new network. That's all there is to it. With just a few steps, you can enjoy the benefits of using a public DNS server for your device. For a bigger impact, you can set your router so all devices using that router will use the public DNS server. I'll cover that in part two. The link is in the description. Thanks for watching. I'll see you soon. [Music]

title: Cisco Tech Talk: How to Change Your DNS Settings with Google DNS, OpenDNS & Cloudflare - Part 2
description:
Welcome back to Cisco Tech Talk! In part two of our DNS series, learn how to change DNS settings on your entire network. Switching to a public DNS like Google DNS ensures every device—PCs, smartphones, printers, smart home gadgets—enjoys faster speeds, better uptime, and enhanced security. 

Why Change DNS at the Router Level? 
Changing the DNS server at the router level means every device that connects to your Wi-Fi network will automatically use your chosen public DNS server, like Google DNS, OpenDNS, or Cloudflare DNS, without needing to configure each device individually. 

Missed part 1? Watch it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hqxy7nL3gGo]

transcript: Welcome back. In part one, I explained the benefits of using a public DNS server and how to change it on an individual device. By changing the DNS at the router level, you ensure that every device on your network benefits from the potentially faster, more reliable, and secure public DNS servers. In this episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll show you how to change DNS servers on an RV 160 wireless ACVPN router. Next, [Music] to change your RV 160 router to use a public DNS, start by accessing the router's web interface. If you know your router's IP address, open a browser and type it in. If you're unsure of the IP address, you can find it by going to the command prompt on your computer. Type ipconfig/all on Windows or if config on Mac or Linux. You can often look for the default gateway under your Ethernet adapter. Common IP addresses for routers are 192.168.1.1, 192.168.0.1 0.1 or 10.0.0.1. However, it is important to note that in some scenarios, the default gateway on the PC will point to another device. If you use a router from your service provider, the IP address may be printed on the router itself or the manual that came with it. Once you have the IP address, enter it into your browser's address bar. You'll be prompted to log in with your username and password. After logging in, look for the DNS settings on the interface which are located on the main page for this model. This is for the WAN interface. The DNS server option will be available under the WAN settings page. Currently, you're most likely using the DNS provided by your internet service provider. To change it, select the use DNS as below checkbox and enter the new address. For Google's public DNS server, that's 8.8.8.8. For a secondary DNS, enter 8.8.4.4. Click the apply button to save the changes to the running configuration file. To save the changes on the startup configuration file, click the red save icon at the top of the page. Restart the router to verify that the changes took effect. Under the administration menu, the reboot option will be available. Click reboot. Select reboot the device. Click reboot and confirm by clicking okay. The router will restart, so you'll need to wait a few moments. Once the router is back online, log in again to confirm that the DNS changes have been applied successfully. Now your router should be using the new public DNS server settings. There you have it. Now devices such as computers, smartphones, smart devices, and printers connected to the network will automatically use the new DNS settings. Thanks for watching. I'll see you next time. [Music]
